causes_spoilage: Growth of bacteria due to improper temperature.
Exposure to air leading to oxidation, discoloration and moisture loss.
home_solutions: Refrigeration: Store beef in the coldest part of the fridge (below 4°C or 40°F) and use it within 3-5 days.
Freezing: Wrap tightly in plastic wrap, aluminum foil, or vacuum-seal before freezing to prevent freezer burn.
Avoiding Cross-Contamination: Store beef away from other foods to prevent cross-contamination.
market_solutions: emperature Control: Keep beef stored at temperatures below 4°C to slow bacterial growth.
Vacuum Packing: Use vacuum-sealed packaging to  reduce oxygen exposure.
Preservative Use: Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C): Acts as an antioxidant, helping to delay discoloration and spoilage by reducing oxidative reactions.

causes_spoilage: Staling due to air exposure and the crystallization of  starch molecules.
home_solutions: Room Temperature Storage: Store bread in a bread box or wrap it in a cloth to maintain moderate humidity and reduce mold growth.
Freezing: Bread can be frozen to prevent spoilage and maintain freshness. Wrap it tightly in plastic wrap before placing it in the freezer.
Avoid Refrigeration: Avoid storing bread in the refrigerator, as it leads to faster staling.
market_solutions: Packaging: Keep beef stored at temperatures below 4°C to slow bacterial growth
Preservative Use: Calcium Propionate: This antifungal agent is used to extend bread shelf life by preventing mold growth.

causes_spoilage: High moisture content leads to mold and bacteria growth.
Mechanical damage (e.g., bruising) can accelerate spoilage.
home_solutions: Room Temperature Storage: Store tomatoes at room temperature (above 10°C or 50°F) to retain their flavor
Avoid Refrigeration: Refrigerating tomatoes can affect their taste and texture negatively.
market_solutions: Packaging: Use well-ventilated boxes to ensure adequate airflow.
Temperature Control: Store tomatoes in a cool area, but not refrigerated.
Preservative Use: No specific preservatives are recommended for tomatoes, but good handling practices and controlled temperatures help extend shelf life.
